ModuleName: Comparison of Length, Weight, Capacity, and Numbers to 10
Description:
Identify whether the number of objects in one group is greater than, less 
than, or equal to the number of objects in another group, e.g., by using 
matching and counting strategies.1
Goal: Compare Numbers

ModuleName: Comparison of Length, Weight, Capacity, and Numbers to 10
Description: Compare two numbers between 1 and 10 presented as written numerals.
Goal: Compare Numbers

ModuleName: Count to 100 by Ones and Tens
Description:
Understand the relationship between numbers and quantities; connect 
counting to cardinality.
Goal: Count to tell the number of objects.

ModuleName: Analyzing, Comparing, and Composing Shapes
Description:
Understand the relationship between numbers and quantities; connect 
counting to cardinality.
Goal: Count to tell the number of objects.

ModuleName: Numbers to 10
Description:
When counting objects, say the number names in the standard order, pairing 
each object with one and only one number name and each number name with one 
and only one object.
Goal: Count to tell the number of objects.

ModuleName: Numbers to 10
Description:
Understand that the last number name said tells the number of objects 
counted. The number of objects is the same regardless of their arrangement 
or the order in which they were counted.
Goal: Count to tell the number of objects.

ModuleName: Numbers to 10
Description:
Understand that each successive number name refers to a quantity that is 
one larger.
Goal: Count to tell the number of objects.

ModuleName: Numbers to 10
Description:
Count to answer “how many?” questions about as many as 20 things arranged 
in a line, a rectangular array, or a circle, or as many as 10 things in a 
scattered configuration; given a number from 1–20, count out that many 
objects.
Goal: Count to tell the number of objects.

ModuleName: Count to 100 by Ones and Tens
Description:
Count to answer “how many?” questions about as many as 20 things arranged 
in a line, a rectangular array, or a circle, or as many as 10 things in a 
scattered configuration; given a number from 1–20, count out that many 
objects.
Goal: Count to tell the number of objects.

ModuleName: Count to 100 by Ones and Tens
Description: Count to 100 by ones and by tens.
Goal: Know number names and the count sequence

ModuleName: Count to 100 by Ones and Tens
Description:
Count forward beginning from a given number within the known sequence 
(instead of having to begin at 1).
Goal: Know number names and the count sequence

ModuleName: Numbers to 10
Description:
Write numbers from 0 to 20. Represent a number of objects with a written 
numeral 0-20 (with 0 representing a count of no objects).
Goal: Know number names and the count sequence

ModuleName: Count to 100 by Ones and Tens
Description:
Write numbers from 0 to 20. Represent a number of objects with a written 
numeral 0-20 (with 0 representing a count of no objects).
Goal: Know number names and the count sequence

Description:
Represent addition and subtraction with objects, fingers, mental images, 
drawings2, sounds (e.g., claps), acting out situations, verbal 
explanations, expressions, or equations.
Goal:
Understand addition as putting together and adding to, and understand subtraction as taking apart and taking
from.

Description:
Solve addition and subtraction word problems, and add and subtract within 
10, e.g., by using objects or drawings to represent the problem.
Goal:
Understand addition as putting together and adding to, and understand subtraction as taking apart and taking
from.

ModuleName: Numbers to 10
Description:
Decompose numbers less than or equal to 10 into pairs in more than one way, 
e.g., by using objects or drawings, and record each decomposition by a 
drawing or equation (e.g., 5 = 2 + 3 and 5 = 4 + 1).
Goal:
Understand addition as putting together and adding to, and understand subtraction as taking apart and taking
from.

ModuleName: Numbers to 10
Description:
Decompose numbers less than or equal to 10 into pairs in more than one way, 
e.g., by using objects or drawings, and record each decomposition by a 
drawing or equation (e.g., 5 = 2 + 3 and 5 = 4 + 1).
Goal:
Understand addition as putting together and adding to, and understand subtraction as taking apart and taking
from.

Description:
For any number from 1 to 9, find the number that makes 10 when added to the 
given number, e.g., by using objects or drawings, and record the answer 
with a drawing or equation.
Goal:
Understand addition as putting together and adding to, and understand subtraction as taking apart and taking
from.

Description: Fluently add and subtract within 5.
Goal:
Understand addition as putting together and adding to, and understand subtraction as taking apart and taking
from.

ModuleName: Count to 100 by Ones and Tens
Description:
Compose and decompose numbers from 11 to 19 into ten ones and some further 
ones, e.g., by using objects or drawings, and record each composition or 
decomposition by a drawing or equation (e.g., 18 = 10 + 8); understand that 
these numbers are composed of ten ones and one, two, three, four, five, 
six, seven, eight, or nine ones.
Goal: Work With Numbers 11–19 To Gain Foundations For Place Value.
SUBJECTL2: Number And Operations In Base Ten

ModuleName: Numbers to 10
Description:
Classify objects into given categories; count the numbers of objects in 
each category and sort the categories by count. Limit category counts to be less than or equal to 10.
Goal: Classify objects and count the number of objects in each category.
SUBJECTL3: Numbers to 10^13 and Two-Dimensional and Three-Dimensional Shapes

ModuleName: Comparison of Length, Weight, Capacity, and Numbers to 10
Description:
Describe measurable attributes of objects, such as length or weight. 
Describe several measurable attributes of a single object.
Goal: Compare numbers.

ModuleName: Comparison of Length, Weight, Capacity, and Numbers to 10
Description:
Directly compare two objects with a measurable attribute in common, to see 
which object has “more of”/“less of” the attribute, and describe the 
difference. For example, directly compare the heights of two children and 
describe one child as taller/shorter.
Goal: Compare numbers.

ModuleName: wo-Dimensional and Three-Dimensional Shapes
Description:
Analyze and compare two- and three-dimensional shapes, in different sizes 
and orientations, using informal language to describe their similarities, 
differences, parts (e.g., number of sides and vertices/“corners”) and other 
attributes (e.g., having sides of equal length).
Goal: Analyze, compare, create, and compose shapes.

ModuleName: Analyzing, Comparing, and Composing Shapes
Description:
Model shapes in the world by building shapes from components (e.g., sticks 
and clay balls) and drawing shapes.
Goal: Analyze, Compare, Create, And Compose Shapes.

ModuleName: Analyzing, Comparing, and Composing Shapes
Description:
Compose simple shapes to form larger shapes. For example, “Can you join 
these two triangles with full sides touching to make a rectangle?”
Goal: Analyze, Compare, Create, And Compose Shapes.

ModuleName: wo-Dimensional and Three-Dimensional Shapes
Description:
Describe objects in the environment using names of shapes, and describe the 
relative positions of these objects using terms such as above, below, 
beside, in front of, behind, and next to.
Goal: Identify and describe shapes (squares, circles, triangles, rectangles, hexagons, cubes, cones, cylinders, and spheres).

ModuleName: wo-Dimensional and Three-Dimensional Shapes
Description: Correctly name shapes regardless of their orientations or overall size.
Goal: Identify and describe shapes (squares, circles, triangles, rectangles, hexagons, cubes, cones, cylinders, and spheres).

ModuleName: wo-Dimensional and Three-Dimensional Shapes
Description:
Identify shapes as two-dimensional (lying in a plane, “flat”) or three- 
dimensional (“solid”).
Goal: Identify and describe shapes (squares, circles, triangles, rectangles, hexagons, cubes, cones, cylinders, and spheres).

ModuleName: Sums and Differences to 10
Description:
Use addition and subtraction within 20 to solve word problems involving situations of adding to,
taking from, putting together, taking apart and comparing, with unknowns in all positions, e.g.,
by using objects, drawings and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent
the problem. (See Glossary, Table 1.)
Goal: Represent and solve problems involving addition and subtraction.

ModuleName: Sums and Differences to 10
Description:
Apply properties of operations as strategies to add and subtract. (Students need not use formal
terms for these properties.) Examples: If 8 + 3 = 11 is known, then 3 + 8 = 11 is also known.
(Commutative property of addition.) To add 2 + 6 + 4, the second two numbers can be added to
make a ten, so 2 + 6 + 4 = 2 + 10 = 12. (Associative property of addition.)
Goal: Understand and apply properties of operations and the relationship between addition and subtraction.

ModuleName: Sums and Differences to 10
Description:
Understand subtraction as an unknown-addend problem. For example, subtract 10 – 8 by finding
the number that makes 10 when added to 8.
Goal: Understand and apply properties of operations and the relationship between addition and subtraction.

ModuleName: Sums and Differences to 10
Description: Relate counting to addition and subtraction (e.g., by counting on 2 to add 2).
Goal: Add and subtract within 20.

ModuleName: Sums and Differences to 10
Description:
Add and subtract within 20, demonstrating fluency for addition and subtraction within 10. Use
strategies such as counting on; making ten (e.g., 8 + 6 = 8 + 2 + 4 = 10 + 4 = 14); decomposing a
number leading to a ten (e.g., 13 – 4 = 13 – 3 – 1 = 10 – 1 = 9); using the relationship between
addition and subtraction (e.g., knowing that 8 + 4 = 12, one knows 12 – 8 = 4); and creating
equivalent but easier or known sums (e.g., adding 6 + 7 by creating the known equivalent 6 + 6 +
1 = 12 + 1 = 13).
Goal: Add and subtract within 20.

ModuleName: Sums and Differences to 10
Description:
Understand the meaning of the equal sign, and determine if equations involving addition and
subtraction are true or false. For example, which of the following equations are true and which
are false? 6 = 6, 7 = 8 – 1, 5 + 2 = 2 + 5, 4 + 1 = 5 + 2.
Goal: Work with addition and subtraction equations.

ModuleName: Sums and Differences to 10
Description:
Determine the unknown whole number in an addition or subtraction equation relating three
whole numbers. For example, determine the unknown number that makes the equation true in
each of the equations 8 + ? = 11, 5 = ? - 3, 6 + 6 = ?.
Goal: Work with addition and subtraction equations.

ModuleName: Introduction to Place Value Through Additon and Subtraction Within 20
Description:
Use addition and subtraction within 20 to solve word problems involving situations of adding to,
taking from, putting together, taking apart, and comparing, with unknowns in all positions, e.g.,
by using objects, drawings, and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent
the problem. (See Glossary, Table 1.)
Goal: Represent and solve problems involving addition and subtraction.

ModuleName: Introduction to Place Value Through Additon and Subtraction Within 20
Description:
Solve word problems that call for addition of three whole numbers whose sum is less than or
equal to 20, e.g., by using objects, drawings, and equations with a symbol for the unknown
number to represent the problem.
Goal: Represent and solve problems involving addition and subtraction.

ModuleName: Introduction to Place Value Through Additon and Subtraction Within 20
Description:
Apply properties of operations as strategies to add and subtract. (Students need not use formal
terms for these properties.) Examples: If 8 + 3 = 11 is known, then 3 + 8 = 11 is also known.
(Commutative property of addition.) To add 2 + 6 + 4, the second two numbers can be added to
make a ten, so 2 + 6 + 4 = 2 + 10 = 12. (Associative property of addition.)
Goal: Understand and apply properties of operations and the relationship between addition and subtraction.

ModuleName: Introduction to Place Value Through Additon and Subtraction Within 20
Description:
Understand subtraction as an unknown-addend problem. For example, subtract 10 – 8 by finding
the number that makes 10 when added to 8.
Goal: Understand and apply properties of operations and the relationship between addition and subtraction.

ModuleName: Introduction to Place Value Through Additon and Subtraction Within 20
Description:
Add and subtract within 20, demonstrating fluency for addition and subtraction within 10. Use
strategies such as counting on; making ten (e.g., 8 + 6 = 8 + 2 + 4 = 10 + 4 = 14); decomposing a number leading to a ten (e.g., 13 – 4 = 13 – 3 – 1 = 10 – 1 = 9); using the relationship between
addition and subtraction (e.g., knowing that 8 + 4 = 12, one knows 12 – 8 = 4); and creating
equivalent but easier or known sums (e.g., adding 6 + 7 by creating the known equivalent 6 + 6 +
1 = 12 + 1 = 13).
Goal: Represent and solve problems involving addition and subtraction.

ModuleName: Introduction to Place Value Through Additon and Subtraction Within 20
Description:
Understand that the two digits of a two-digit number represent amounts of tens and ones.
Understand the following as special cases:
a. 10 can be thought of as a bundle of ten ones – called a “ten.”
b. The numbers from 11 to 19 are composed of a ten and one, two, three, four, five, six, seven,
eight, or nine ones.
Goal: Understand place value.
SUBJECTL2: NUMBERS AND OPERATIONS IN BASE TEN

ModuleName:
Ordering and Comparing Length
Measurements as Numbers
Description:
Order three objects by length; compare the lengths of two objects indirectly by using a third
object.
Goal: Measure lengths indirectly and by iterating length units.

ModuleName:
Ordering and Comparing Length
Measurements as Numbers
Description:
Express the length of an object as a whole number of length units, by laying multiple copies of a
shorter object (the length unit) end to end; understand that the length measurement of an
object is the number of same-size length units that span it with no gaps or overlaps. Limit to
contexts where the object being measured is spanned by a whole number of length units with no
gaps or overlaps.
Goal: Measure lengths indirectly and by iterating length units.

ModuleName:
Ordering and Comparing Length
Measurements as Numbers
Description:
Organize, represent, and interpret data with up to three categories; ask and answer questions
about the total number of data points, how many in each category, and how many more or less
are in one category than in another.
Goal: Represent and interpret data.

ModuleName:
Ordering and Comparing Length
Measurements as Numbers
Description:
Use addition and subtraction within 20 to solve word problems involving situations of adding to,
taking from, putting together, taking apart, and comparing, with unknowns in all positions, e.g.,
by using objects, drawings, and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent
the problem. (See Glossary, Table 1.)
Goal: Represent and solve problems involving addition and subtraction.

ModuleName:
Place Value, Comparison,
Addition and Subtraction to 40
Description:
Use addition and subtraction within 20 to solve word problems involving situations of adding to,
taking from, putting together, taking apart, and comparing, with unknowns in all positions, e.g.,
by using objects, drawings, and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent
the problem. (See Glossary, Table 1.)
Goal: Represent and solve problems involving addition and subtraction.

ModuleName:
Place Value, Comparison,
Addition and Subtraction to 40
Description:
Count to 120, starting at any number less than 120. In this range, read and write numerals and
represent a number of objects with a written numeral.
Goal: Extend the counting sequence.
SUBJECTL2: NUMBERS AND OPERATIONS IN BASE TEN

ModuleName:
Place Value, Comparison,
Addition and Subtraction to 40
Description:
Understand that the two digits of a two-digit number represent amounts of tens and ones.
Understand the following as special cases:
a. 10 can be thought of as a bundle of ten ones – called a “ten.”
c. The numbers 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70, 80, 90 refer to one, two, three, four, five, six, seven,
eight, or nine tens (and 0 ones).
Goal: Understand place value.
SUBJECTL2: NUMBERS AND OPERATIONS IN BASE TEN

ModuleName:
Place Value, Comparison,
Addition and Subtraction to 40
Description:
Compare two two-digit numbers based on meanings of the tens and ones digits, recording the
results of comparisons with the symbols >, =, and <.
Goal: Understand place value.
SUBJECTL2: NUMBERS AND OPERATIONS IN BASE TEN

ModuleName:
Place Value, Comparison,
Addition and Subtraction to 40
Description:
Add within 100, including adding a two-digit number and a one-digit number, and adding a two-
digit number and a multiple of 10, using concrete models or drawings and strategies based on
place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction;
relate the strategy to a written method and explain the reasoning used. Understand that in
adding two-digit numbers, one adds tens and tens, ones and ones; and sometimes it is necessary
to compose a ten.
Goal: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to add and subtract.
SUBJECTL2: NUMBERS AND OPERATIONS IN BASE TEN

ModuleName:
Place Value, Comparison,
Addition and Subtraction to 40
Description:
Given a two-digit number, mentally find 10 more or 10 less than the number, without having to
count; explain the reasoning used.
Goal: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to add and subtract.
SUBJECTL2: NUMBERS AND OPERATIONS IN BASE TEN

Description:
Subtract multiples of 10 in the range 10-90 from multiples of 10 in the range 10-90 (positive or
zero differences), using concrete models or drawings and strategies based on place value,
properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction; relate the
strategy to a written method and explain the reasoning used.
Goal: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to add and subtract.
SUBJECTL2: NUMBERS AND OPERATIONS IN BASE TEN

ModuleName:
Identifying, Composing, and
Partitioning Shapes
Description:
Tell and write time in hours and half-hours using analog and digital clocks. Recognize and identify
coins, their names, and their value.
Goal: Tell and write time and money.
SUBJECTL2: NUMBERS AND OPERATIONS IN BASE TEN

ModuleName:
Identifying, Composing, and
Partitioning Shapes
Description:
Distinguish between defining attributes (e.g., triangles are closed and three-sided) versus non-
defining attributes (e.g., color, orientation, overall size); build and draw shapes to possess
defining attributes.
Goal: Reason with shapes and their attributes.
SUBJECTL2: NUMBERS AND OPERATIONS IN BASE TEN

ModuleName:
Identifying, Composing, and
Partitioning Shapes
Description:
Compose two-dimensional shapes (rectangles, squares, trapezoids, triangles, half-circles, and
quarter-circles) or three-dimensional shapes (cubes, right rectangular prisms, right circular
cones, and right circular cylinders) to create a composite shape, and compose new shapes from
the composite shape. (Students do not need to learn formal names such as “right rectangular
prism.)
Goal: Reason with shapes and their attributes.
SUBJECTL2: NUMBERS AND OPERATIONS IN BASE TEN

ModuleName:
Identifying, Composing, and
Partitioning Shapes
Description:
Partition circles and rectangles into two and four equal shares, describe the shares using the words halves, fourths, and quarters, and use the phrases half of, fourth of, and quarter of.
Describe the whole as two of, or four of the shares. Understand for these examples that
decomposing into more equal shares creates smaller shares.
Goal: Reason with shapes and their attributes.
SUBJECTL2: NUMBERS AND OPERATIONS IN BASE TEN

ModuleName:
Place Value, Comparison,
Addition and Subtraction to 100
Description:
Count to 120, starting at any number less than 120. In this range, read and write numerals and
represent a number of objects with a written numeral.
Goal: Extend the counting sequence.
SUBJECTL2: NUMBERS AND OPERATIONS IN BASE TEN

ModuleName:
Place Value, Comparison,
Addition and Subtraction to 100
Description:
Understand that the two digits of a two-digit number represent amounts of tens and ones.
Understand the following as special cases:
a. 10 can be thought of as a bundle of ten ones – called a “ten.”
c. The numbers 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70, 80, 90 refer to one, two, three, four, five, six, seven,
eight, or nine tens (and 0 ones).
Goal: Understand place value.
SUBJECTL2: NUMBERS AND OPERATIONS IN BASE TEN

ModuleName:
Place Value, Comparison,
Addition and Subtraction to 100
Description:
Compare two two-digit numbers based on meanings of the tens and ones digits, recording the
results of comparisons with the symbols >, =, and <.
Goal: Understand place value.
SUBJECTL2: NUMBERS AND OPERATIONS IN BASE TEN

ModuleName:
Place Value, Comparison,
Addition and Subtraction to 100
Description:
Add within 100, including adding a two-digit number and a one-digit number, and adding a two-
digit number and a multiple of 10, using concrete models or drawings and strategies based on
place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction;
relate the strategy to a written method and explain the reasoning used. Understand that in
adding two-digit numbers, one adds tens and tens, ones and ones; and sometimes it is necessary
to compose a ten.
Goal: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to add and subtract.
SUBJECTL2: NUMBERS AND OPERATIONS IN BASE TEN

ModuleName:
Place Value, Comparison,
Addition and Subtraction to 100
Description:
Given a two-digit number, mentally find 10 more or 10 less than the number, without having to
count: explain the reasoning used.
Goal: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to add and subtract.
SUBJECTL2: NUMBERS AND OPERATIONS IN BASE TEN

ModuleName:
Place Value, Comparison,
Addition and Subtraction to 100
Description:
Subtract multiples of 10 in the range 10-90 from multiples of 10 in the range 10-90 (positive or
zero differences), using concrete models or drawings and strategies based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction; relate the
strategy to a written method and explain the reasoning used.
Goal: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to add and subtract.
SUBJECTL2: NUMBERS AND OPERATIONS IN BASE TEN

ModuleName:
Place Value, Comparison,
Addition and Subtraction to 100
Description:
Tell and write time in hours and half-hours using analog and digital clocks. Recognize and identify
coins, their names, and their value.
Goal: Tell and write time and money.
SUBJECTL2: NUMBERS AND OPERATIONS IN BASE TEN

ModuleName: Sums and Differences to 20
Description:
Use addition and subtraction within 100 to solve one- and two-step word problems involving
situations of adding to, taking from, putting together, taking apart, and comparing, with
unknowns in all positions, e.g., by using drawings and equations with a symbol for the unknown
number to represent the problem. (See Glossary, Table 1.)
Goal: Represent and solve problems involving addition and subtraction.

ModuleName: Sums and Differences to 20
Description:
Fluently add and subtract within 20 using mental strategies. (See standard 1.OA.6 for a list of
mental strategies.) By end of grade 2, know from memory all sums of two one-digit numbers.
Goal: Add and subtract within 20.

ModuleName: Sums and Differences to 20
Description:
Fluently add and subtract within 100 using strategies based on place value, properties of
operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction.
Goal: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to add and subtract.
SUBJECTL2: NUMBERS AND OPERATIONS IN BASE TEN

ModuleName:
Addition and Subtraction of
Length Units
Description: Measure the length of an object by selecting and using appropriate tools such as rulers, yardsticks, meter sticks, and measuring tapes.
Goal: Measure and estimate lengths in standard units.

ModuleName:
Addition and Subtraction of
Length Units
Description: Measure the length of an object twice, using length units of different lengths for the two measurements; describe how the two measurements relate to the size of the unit chosen.
Goal: Measure and estimate lengths in standard units.

ModuleName:
Addition and Subtraction of
Length Units
Description: Estimate lengths using units of inches, feet, centimeters, and meters.
Goal: Measure and estimate lengths in standard units.

ModuleName:
Addition and Subtraction of
Length Units
Description: Measure to determine how much longer one object is than another, expressing the length
Goal: Measure and estimate lengths in standard units.

ModuleName:
Addition and Subtraction of
Length Units
Description:
Use addition and subtraction within 100 to solve word problems involving lengths that are given
in the same units, e.g., by using drawings (such as drawings of rulers) and equations with a
symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem.
Goal: Relate addition and subtraction to length

ModuleName:
Addition and Subtraction of
Length Units
Description:
Represent whole numbers as lengths from 0 on a number line diagram with equally spaced
points corresponding to the numbers 0, 1, 2, ..., and represent whole-number sums and
differences within 100 on a number line diagram.
Goal: Relate addition and subtraction to length

ModuleName:
Place Value, Counting, and
Comparison of Numbers to
1000
Description:
Understand that the three digits of a three-digit number represent amounts of hundreds, tens
and ones; e.g., 706 equals 7 hundreds, 0 tens, and 6 ones. Understand the following as special
cases:
a. 100 can be thought of as a bundle of ten tens – called a “hundred.”
b. The numbers 100, 200, 300, 400, 500, 600, 700, 800, 900 refer to one, two, three, four, five,
six, seven, eight, or nine hundreds (and 0 tens and 0 ones).
Goal: Understand place value.
SUBJECTL2: NUMBERS AND OPERATIONS IN BASE TEN

ModuleName:
Place Value, Counting, and
Comparison of Numbers to
1000
Description: Count within 1000; skip-count by 5s 42, 10s, and 100s.
Goal: Understand place value.
SUBJECTL2: NUMBERS AND OPERATIONS IN BASE TEN

ModuleName:
Place Value, Counting, and
Comparison of Numbers to
1000
Description: Read and write numbers to 1000 using base-ten numerals, number names, and expanded form.
Goal: Understand place value.
SUBJECTL2: NUMBERS AND OPERATIONS IN BASE TEN

ModuleName:
Place Value, Counting, and
Comparison of Numbers to
Description:
Compare two three-digit numbers based on meanings of the hundreds, tens, and ones digits,
using >, =, and < symbols to record the results of comparisons.
Goal: Understand place value.
SUBJECTL2: NUMBERS AND OPERATIONS IN BASE TEN

ModuleName: Addition and Subtraction
Description:
"Use addition and subtraction within 100 to solve one- and two-step word problems involving
situations of adding to, taking from, putting together, taking apart, and comparing, with"
unknowns in all positions, e.g., by using drawings and equations with a symbol for the unknown
number to represent the problem. (See Glossary, Table 1.)
Goal: Represent and solve problems involving addition and subtraction.

ModuleName: Addition and Subtraction
Description:
Fluently add and subtract within 100 using strategies based on place value, properties of
operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction.
Goal: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to add and subtract.
SUBJECTL2: NUMBERS AND OPERATIONS IN BASE TEN

ModuleName: Addition and Subtraction
Description:
Add up to four two-digit numbers using strategies based on place value and properties of
operations.
Goal: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to add and subtract.
SUBJECTL2: NUMBERS AND OPERATIONS IN BASE TEN

ModuleName: Addition and Subtraction
Description:
Add and subtract within 1000, using concrete models or drawings and strategies based on place
value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction; relate
the strategy to a written method. Understand that in adding or subtracting three-digit numbers,
one adds or subtracts hundreds and hundreds, tens and tens, ones and ones; and sometimes it is
necessary to compose or decompose tens or hundreds.
Goal: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to add and subtract.
SUBJECTL2: NUMBERS AND OPERATIONS IN BASE TEN

ModuleName: Addition and Subtraction
Description:
Mentally add 10 or 100 to a given number 100-900, and mentally subtract 10 or 100 from a given
number 100-900.
Goal: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to add and subtract.
SUBJECTL2: NUMBERS AND OPERATIONS IN BASE TEN

ModuleName: Addition and Subtraction
Description:
Explain why addition and subtraction strategies work, using place value and the properties of
operations. (Explanations may be supported by drawings or objects.)
Goal: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to add and subtract.
SUBJECTL2: NUMBERS AND OPERATIONS IN BASE TEN

ModuleName:
Addition and Subtraction
Within 1000 with Word
Problems to 100
Description:
Add and subtract within 1000, using concrete models or drawings and strategies based on place
value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction; relate
the strategy to a written method. Understand that in adding or subtracting three-digit numbers,
one adds or subtracts hundreds and hundreds, tens and tens, ones and ones; and sometimes it is
necessary to compose or decompose tens or hundreds.
Goal: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to add and subtract.
SUBJECTL2: NUMBERS AND OPERATIONS IN BASE TEN

ModuleName:
Addition and Subtraction
Within 1000 with Word
Problems to 100
Description: Mentally add 10 or 100 to a given number 100-900, and mentally subtract 10 or 100 from a given number 100-900.
Goal: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to add and subtract.
SUBJECTL2: NUMBERS AND OPERATIONS IN BASE TEN

ModuleName:
Addition and Subtraction
Within 1000 with Word
Problems to 100
Description:
Explain why addition and subtraction strategies work, using place value and the properties of
operations. (Explanations may be supported by drawings or objects.)
Goal: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to add and subtract.
SUBJECTL2: NUMBERS AND OPERATIONS IN BASE TEN

ModuleName: Foudations of Multplication and Division
Description:
Determine whether a group of objects (up to 20) has an odd or even number of members, e.g.,
by pairing objects or counting them by 2s: write an equation to express an even number as a
sum of two equal addends.
Goal: Work with equal groups of objects to gain foundations for multiplication.

ModuleName: Foudations of Multplication and Division
Description:
Use addition to find the total number of objects arranged in rectangular arrays with up to 5 rows
and up to 5 columns; write an equation to express the total as a sum of equal addends.
Goal: Work with equal groups of objects to gain foundations for multiplication.

ModuleName: Foudations of Multplication and Division
Description:
Partition a rectangle into rows and columns of same size squares and count to find the total
number of them.
Goal: Reason with shapes and their attributes.

ModuleName: Problem Solving with Length, Money, and Data
Description:
Measure the length of an object by selecting and using appropriate tools such as rulers,
yardsticks, meter sticks, and measuring tapes.
Goal: Measure and estimate lengths in standard units.

ModuleName: Problem Solving with Length, Money, and Data
Description:
Measure the length of an object twice, using length units of different lengths for the two
measurements; describe how the two measurements relate to the size of the unit chosen.
Goal: Measure and estimate lengths in standard units.

ModuleName: Problem Solving with Length, Money, and Data
Description: Estimate lengths using units of inches, feet, centimeters, and meters.
Goal: Measure and estimate lengths in standard units.

ModuleName: Problem Solving with Length, Money, and Data
Description:
Measure to determine how much longer one object is than another, expressing the length
difference in terms of a standard length unit.
Goal: Measure and estimate lengths in standard units.

ModuleName: Problem Solving with Length, Money, and Data
Description:
Use addition and subtraction within 100 to solve word problems involving lengths that are given
in the same units, e.g., by using drawings (such as drawings of rulers) and equations with a
symbol for the unknown number to represent the problems.
Goal: Relate addition and subtraction to length.

ModuleName: Problem Solving with Length, Money, and Data
Description:
Represent whole numbers as lengths from 0 on a number line diagram with equally spaced
points corresponding to the numbers 0, 1, 2, ..., and represent whole-number sums and
differences within 100 on a number line diagram.
Goal: Relate addition and subtraction to length.

ModuleName: Problem Solving with Length, Money, and Data
Description:
Solve word problems involving dollar bills, quarters, dimes, nickels, and pennies, using $ and ¢
symbols appropriately. Example: If you have 2 dimes and 3 pennies, how many cents do you
have?
Goal: Work with time and money.

ModuleName: Problem Solving with Length, Money, and Data
Description:
Generate measurement data by measuring lengths of several objects to the nearest whole unit,
or by making repeated measurements of the same object. Show the measurements by making a
line plot, where the horizontal scale is marked off in whole-number units.
Goal: Represent and interpret data.

ModuleName: Problem Solving with Length, Money, and Data
Description:
Draw a picture graph and a bar graph (with single-unit scale) to represent a data set with up to
four categories. Solve simple put-together, take-apart, and compare problems (See Glossary,
Table 1.) using information presented in a bar graph.
Goal: Represent and interpret data.

ModuleName: TIme, Shapes, and Fractions as Equal Parts of Shapes
Description:
Tell time and write time from analog and digital clocks to the nearest five minutes, using a.m.
and p.m.
Goal: Work with time and money.

ModuleName: TIme, Shapes, and Fractions as Equal Parts of Shapes
Description:
Recognize and draw shapes having specified attributes, such as a given number of angles or a
given number of equal faces. (Sizes are compared directly or visually, not compared by measuring.) Identify triangles, quadrilaterals, pentagons, hexagons, and cubes.
Goal: Reason with shapes and their attributes.

ModuleName: TIme, Shapes, and Fractions as Equal Parts of Shapes
Description:
Partition circles and rectangles into two, three, or four equal shares, describe the shares using
the words halves, thirds, half of, a third of, etc., and describe the whole as two halves, three
thirds, four fourths. Recognize that equal shares of identical wholes need not have the same
shape.
Goal: Reason with shapes and their attributes.

ModuleName:
Properties of Multiplication and
Division and Solving Problems
with Units of 2–5 and 10
Description:
Interpret products of whole numbers, e.g., interpret 5 x 7 as the total number of objects in 5
groups of 7 objects each. For example, describe a context in which a total number of objects can
be expressed as 5 x 7
Goal: Represent and solve problems involving multiplication and divison.

ModuleName:
Properties of Multiplication and
Division and Solving Problems
with Units of 2–5 and 10
Description:
Interpret whole-number quotients of whole numbers, e.g., interpret 56 ÷ 8 as the number of objects in each share when 56 objects are partitioned equally into 8 shares, or as a number of
shares when 56 objects are partitioned into equal shares of 8 objects each. For example, describe
a context in which a number of shares or a number of groups can be expressed as 56 ÷ 8.
Goal: Represent and solve problems involving multiplication and divison.

ModuleName:
Properties of Multiplication and
Division and Solving Problems
with Units of 2–5 and 10
Description:
Use multiplication and division within 100 to solve word problems in situations involving equal
groups, arrays, and measurement quantities, e.g., by using drawings and equations with a
symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem. (See Glossary, Table 2.)
Goal: Represent and solve problems involving multiplication and divison.

ModuleName:
Properties of Multiplication and
Division and Solving Problems
with Units of 2–5 and 10
Description:
Determine the unknown whole number in a multiplication or division equation relating three
whole numbers. For example, determine the unknown number that makes the equation true in
each of the equations 8 x ? = 48, 5 = _ ÷ 3, 6 x 6 = ?
Goal: Represent and solve problems involving multiplication and divison.

ModuleName:
Properties of Multiplication and
Division and Solving Problems
with Units of 2–5 and 10
Description:
Apply properties of operations as strategies to multiply and divide. (Students need not use
formal terms for these properties.) Examples: If 6 × 4 = 24 is known, then 4 × 6 = 24 is also
known. (Commutative property of multiplication.) 3 × 5 × 2 can be found by 3 × 5 = 15, then 15 ×
2 = 30, or by 5 × 2 = 10, then 3 × 10 = 30. (Associative property of multiplication.) Knowing that 8
× 5 = 40 and 8 × 2 = 16, one can find 8 × 7 as 8 × (5 + 2) = (8 × 5) + (8 × 2) = 40 + 16 = 56.
(Distributive property.)
Goal: Understand properties of multiplication and the relationship between multiplication and division.

ModuleName:
Properties of Multiplication and
Division and Solving Problems
with Units of 2–5 and 10
Description:
Understand division as an unknown-factor problem. For example, find 32 ÷ 8 by finding the
number that makes 32 when multiplied by 8.
Goal: Understand properties of multiplication and the relationship between multiplication and division.

ModuleName:
Properties of Multiplication and
Division and Solving Problems
with Units of 2–5 and 10
Description:
Fluently multiply and divide within 100, using strategies such as the relationship between
multiplication and division (e.g., knowing that 8 × 5 = 40, one knows 40 ÷ 5 = 8) or properties of
operations. By the end of Grade 3, know from memory all products of two one-digit numbers.
Goal: Multiply and divide within 100.

ModuleName:
Properties of Multiplication and
Division and Solving Problems
with Units of 2–5 and 10
Description:
Solve two-step word problems using the four operations. Represent these problems using
equations with a letter standing for the unknown quantity. Assess the reasonableness of
answers using mental computation and estimation strategies including rounding. (This standard
is limited to problems posed with whole numbers and having whole-number answers; students
should know how to perform operations in the conventional order when there are no
parentheses to specify a particular order, i.e., Order of Operations.)
Goal: Solve problems involving the four operations and identify and explain patterns in arithmetic.

ModuleName:
Place Value and Problem
Solving with Units of Measure
Description: Use place value understanding to round whole numbers to the nearest 10 or 100.
Goal:
Use place value understanding and properties of operations to perform multi-digit arithmetic. (A range of
algorithms may be used.

ModuleName:
Place Value and Problem
Solving with Units of Measure
Description:
Fluently add and subtract within 1000 using strategies and algorithms based on place value,
properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction.
Goal:
Use place value understanding and properties of operations to perform multi-digit arithmetic. (A range of
algorithms may be used.

ModuleName:
Place Value and Problem
Solving with Units of Measure
Description:
Tell and write time to the nearest minute and measure time intervals in minutes. Solve word
problems involving addition and subtraction of time intervals in minutes, e.g., by representing
the problem on a number line diagram.
Goal: Solve problems involving measurement and estimation of intervals of time, liquid volumes, and masses of objects.

ModuleName:
Place Value and Problem
Solving with Units of Measure
Description:
Measure and estimate liquid volumes and masses of objects using standard units of grams (g),
kilograms (kg), and liters (l). (Excludes compound units such as cm 3 and finding the geometric
volume of a container.) Add, subtract, multiply, or divide to solve one-step word problems
involving masses or volumes that are given in the same units, e.g., by using drawings (such as a
beaker with a measurement scale) to represent the problem. (Excludes multiplicative
comparison problems, i.e., problems involving notions of “times as much”; see Glossary, Table
2.)
Goal: Solve problems involving measurement and estimation of intervals of time, liquid volumes, and masses of objects.

ModuleName:
Multiplication and Division with
Units of 0, 1, 6–9, and Multiples
of 10
Description:
Use multiplication and division within 100 to solve word problems in situations involving equal
groups, arrays, and measurement quantities, e.g., by using drawings and equations with a
symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem. (See Glossary, Table 2.)
Goal: Represent and solve problems involving multiplication and divison.

ModuleName:
Multiplication and Division with
Units of 0, 1, 6–9, and Multiples
of 10
Description:
Determine the unknown whole number in a multiplication or division equation relating three
whole numbers. For example, determine the unknown number that makes the equation true in
each of the equations 8 x ? = 48, 5 =___÷ 3, 6 x 6 = ?
Goal: Represent and solve problems involving multiplication and divison.

ModuleName:
Multiplication and Division with
Units of 0, 1, 6–9, and Multiples
of 10
Description:
Apply properties of operations as strategies to multiply and divide. (Students need not use
formal terms for these properties.) Examples: If 6 × 4 = 24 is known, then 4 × 6 = 24 is also
known. (Commutative property of multiplication.) 3 × 5 × 2 can be found by 3 × 5 = 15, then 15 ×
2 = 30, or by 5 × 2 = 10, then 3 × 10 = 30. (Associative property of multiplication.) Knowing that 8
× 5 = 40 and 8 × 2 = 16, one can find 8 × 7 as 8 × (5 + 2) = (8 × 5) + (8 × 2) = 40 + 16 = 56.
(Distributive property.)
Goal: Understand the properties of multiplication and the relationship between multiplication and division.

ModuleName:
Multiplication and Division with
Units of 0, 1, 6–9, and Multiples
of 10
Description:
Fluently multiply and divide within 100, using strategies such as the relationship between
multiplication and division (e.g., knowing that 8 × 5 = 40, one knows 40 ÷ 5 = 8) or properties of
operations. By the end of Grade 3, know from memory all products of two one-digit numbers.
Goal: Multiply and divide within 100.

ModuleName:
Multiplication and Division with
Units of 0, 1, 6–9, and Multiples
of 10
Description:
Solve two-step word problems using the four operations. Represent these problems using
equations with a letter standing for the unknown quantity. Assess the reasonableness of
answers using mental computation and estimation strategies including rounding. (This standard
is limited to problems posed with whole numbers and having whole-number answers; students
should know how to perform operations in the conventional order when there are no parentheses to specify a particular order, i.e., Order of Operations.)
Goal: Solve problems involving the four operations and identify and explain patterns in arithmetic.

ModuleName:
Multiplication and Division with
Units of 0, 1, 6–9, and Multiples
of 10
Description:
Identify arithmetic patterns (including patterns in the addition table or multiplication table), and
explain them using properties of operations. For example, observe that 4 times a number is
always even, and explain why 4 times a number can be decomposed into two equal addends.
Goal: Solve problems involving the four operations and identify and explain patterns in arithmetic.

ModuleName:
Multiplication and Division with
Units of 0, 1, 6–9, and Multiples
of 10
Description:
Multiply one-digit whole numbers by multiples of 10 in the range 10–90 (e.g., 9 × 80, 5 × 60)
using strategies based on place value and properties of operations.
Goal: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to perform multi-digit arithmetic.
SUBJECTL2: NUMBERS AND OPERATIONS IN BASE TEN

ModuleName: Multiplication and Area
Description:
Recognize area as an attribute of plane figures and understand concepts of area measurement.
a. A square with side length 1 unit, called “a unit square,” is said to have “one square unit” of
area, and can be used to measure area.
b. A plane figure which can be covered without gaps or overlaps by n unit squares is said to
have an area of n square units
Goal: Geometric measurement: understand concepts of area and relate area to multiplication and to addition.

ModuleName: Multiplication and Area
Description:
Measure areas by counting unit squares (square cm, square m, square in, square ft, and
improvised units).
Goal: Geometric measurement: understand concepts of area and relate area to multiplication and to addition.

ModuleName: Multiplication and Area
Description:
Relate area to the operations of multiplication and addition.
a. Find the area of a rectangle with whole-number side lengths by tiling it, and show that the
area is the same as would be found by multiplying the side lengths.
b. Multiply side lengths to find areas of rectangles with whole-number side lengths in the
context of solving real world and mathematical problems, and represent whole-number
products as rectangular areas in mathematical reasoning.
c. Use tiling to show in a concrete case that the area of a rectangle with whole-number side lengths a and b + c is the sum of a × b and a × c. Use area models to represent the
distributive property in mathematical reasoning.
d. Recognize area as additive. Find areas of rectilinear figures by decomposing them into nonoverlapping
rectangles and adding the areas of the non-overlapping parts, applying this
technique to solve real world problems.
Goal: Geometric measurement: understand concepts of area and relate area to multiplication and to addition.

ModuleName:
Fractions as Numbers on the
Number Line
Description:
Understand a fraction 1/b as the quantity formed by 1 part when a whole is partitioned into b
equal parts; understand a fraction a/b as the quantity formed by a parts of size 1/b
Goal: Develop understanding of fractions as numbers.

ModuleName:
Fractions as Numbers on the
Number Line
Description:
Understand a fraction as a number on the number line; represent fractions on a number line
diagram.
a. Represent a fraction 1/b on a number line diagram by defining the interval from 0 to 1 as
the whole and partitioning it into b equal parts. Recognize that each part has size 1/b and
that the endpoint of the part based at 0 locates the number 1/b on the number line.
b. Represent a fraction a/b on a number line diagram by marking off a lengths 1/b from 0.
Recognize that the resulting interval has size a/b and that its endpoint locates the number
a/b on the number line.
Goal: Develop understanding of fractions as numbers.

ModuleName:
Fractions as Numbers on the
Number Line
Description:
Explain equivalence of fractions in special cases, and compare fractions by reasoning about their
size.
a. Understand two fractions as equivalent (equal) if they are the same size, or the same point
on a number line.
b. Recognize and generate simple equivalent fractions, e.g., 1/2 = 2/4, 4/6 = 2/3). Explain why
the fractions are equivalent, e.g., by using a visual fraction model.
c. Express whole numbers as fractions, and recognize fractions that are equivalent to whole
numbers. Examples: Express 3 in the form 3 = 3/1; recognize that 6/1 = 6; locate 4/4 and 1 at the same point of a number line diagram.
d. Compare two fractions with the same numerator or the same denominator by reasoning
about their size. Recognize that comparisons are valid only when the two fractions refer to
the same whole. Record the results of comparisons with the symbols >, =, or <, and justify
the conclusions, e.g., by using a visual fraction model.
Goal: Develop understanding of fractions as numbers.

ModuleName:
Fractions as Numbers on the
Number Line
Description:
Partition shapes into parts with equal areas. Express the area of each part as a unit fraction of
the whole. For example, partition a shape into 4 parts with equal area and describe the area of
each part as 1⁄4 of the area of the shape.
Goal: Reason with shapes and their attributes

ModuleName: Collecting and Displaying Data
Description:
Draw a scaled picture graph and a scaled bar graph to represent a data set with several
categories. Solve one- and two- step “how many more” and “how many less” problems using
information presented in scaled bar graphs. For example, draw a bar graph in which each square
in the bar graph might represent 5 pets.
Goal: Represent and interpret data.

ModuleName: Collecting and Displaying Data
Description:
Generate measurement data by measuring lengths using rulers marked with halves and fourths
of an inch. Show the data by making a line plot, where the horizontal scale is marked off in
appropriate units – whole numbers, halves, or quarters.
Goal: Represent and interpret data.

ModuleName: Geometry and Measurement Word Problems
Description:
Generate measurement data by measuring lengths using rulers marked with halves and fourths
of an inch. Show the data by making a line plot, where the horizontal scale is marked off in
appropriate units – whole numbers, halves, or quarters.
Goal: Represent and interpret data.

ModuleName: Geometry and Measurement Word Problems
Description:
Solve real world and mathematical problems involving perimeters of polygons, including finding
the perimeter given the side lengths, finding an unknown side length, and exhibiting rectangles
with the same perimeter and different areas or with the same area and different perimeters.
Goal: Geometric measurement: recognize perimeter as an attribute of plane figures and distinguish between linear area measures.

ModuleName: Geometry and Measurement Word Problems
Description:
Understand that shapes in different categories (e.g., rhombuses, rectangles, and others) may
share attributes (e.g., having four sides), and that the shared attributes can define a larger
"category (e.g., quadrilaterals). Recognize rhombuses, rectangles, and squares as examples of
quadrilaterals, and draw examples of quadrilaterals that do not belong to any of these
subcategories."
Goal: Reason with shapes and their attributes.

ModuleName:
Place Value, Rounding, and
Algorithms for Addition and
Subtraction
Description:
Solve multistep word problems posed with whole numbers and having whole-number answers
using the four operations, including problems in which remainders must be interpreted.
Represent these problems using equations with a letter standing for the unknown quantity.
Assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies
including rounding.
Goal: Use the four operations with whole numbers to solve problems.

ModuleName:
Place Value, Rounding, and
Algorithms for Addition and
Subtraction
Description:
Recognize that in a multi-digit whole number, a digit in one place represents ten times what it
represents in the place to its right. For example, recognize that 700 ÷ 70 = 10 by applying
concepts of place value and division.
Goal: Generalize place value understanding for multi-digit whole numbers.
SUBJECTL2: NUMBERS AND OPERATIONS IN BASE TEN

ModuleName:
Place Value, Rounding, and
Algorithms for Addition and
Subtraction
Description:
Read and write multi-digit whole numbers using base-ten numerals, number names, and
expanded form. Compare two multi-digit numbers based on meanings of the digits in each place,
using >, =, and < symbols to record the results of comparisons.
Goal: Generalize place value understanding for multi-digit whole numbers.
SUBJECTL2: NUMBERS AND OPERATIONS IN BASE TEN

ModuleName:
Place Value, Rounding, and
Algorithms for Addition and
Subtraction
Description: Use place value understanding to round multi-digit whole numbers to any place.
Goal: Generalize place value understanding for multi-digit whole numbers.
SUBJECTL2: NUMBERS AND OPERATIONS IN BASE TEN

ModuleName:
Place Value, Rounding, and
Algorithms for Addition and
Subtraction
Description: Fluently add and subtract multi-digit whole numbers using the standard algorithm.
Goal: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to perform multi-digit arithmetic.
SUBJECTL2: NUMBERS AND OPERATIONS IN BASE TEN

ModuleName:
Unit Conversions and Problem
Solving with Metric
Measurement
Description:
Know relative sizes of measurement units within one system of units including km, m, cm; kg, g;
lb, oz.; l, ml; hr, min, sec. Within a single system of measurement, express measurements in a
larger unit in terms of a smaller unit. Record measurement equivalents in a two-column table.
For example, know that 1 ft is 12 times as long as 1 in. Express the length of a 4 ft snake as 48 in.
Generate a conversion table for feet and inches listing the number pairs (1, 12), (2, 24), (3, 36), ...
Goal: Solve problems involving measurement and conversion of measurements from a larger unit to a smaller unit.

ModuleName:
Unit Conversions and Problem
Solving with Metric
Measurement
Description:
Use the four operations to solve word problems involving distances, intervals of time, liquid
volumes, masses of objects, and money, including problems involving simple fractions or
decimals, and problems that require expressing measurements given in a larger unit in terms of
a smaller unit. Represent measurement quantities using diagrams such as number line diagrams
that feature a measurement scale.
Goal: Solve problems involving measurement and conversion of measurements from a larger unit to a smaller unit.

ModuleName:
Multi-Digit Multiplication and
Division
Description:
Interpret a multiplication equation as a comparison, e.g., interpret 35 = 5 x 7 as a statement that
35 is 5 times as many as 7 and 7 times as many as 5. Represent verbal statements of
multiplicative comparisons as multiplication equations.
Goal: Use the four operations with whole numbers to solve problems.

ModuleName:
Multi-Digit Multiplication and
Division
Description:
Multiply or divide to solve word problems involving multiplicative comparison, e.g., by using
drawings and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem,
distinguishing multiplicative comparison from additive comparison. (See Glossary, Table 2.)
Goal: Use the four operations with whole numbers to solve problems.

ModuleName:
Multi-Digit Multiplication and
Division
Description:
Solve multistep word problems posed with whole numbers and having whole-number answers
using the four operations, including problems in which remainders must be interpreted.
Represent these problems using equations with a letter standing for the unknown quantity.
Assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies
including rounding.
Goal: Use the four operations with whole numbers to solve problems.

ModuleName:
Multi-Digit Multiplication and
Division
Description:
Find all factor pairs for a whole number in the range 1–100. Recognize that a whole number is a
multiple of each of its factors. Determine whether a given whole number in the range 1–100 is a
multiple of a given one-digit number. Determine whether a given whole number in the range 1–
100 is prime or composite.
Goal: Gain familiarity with factors and multiplies.

ModuleName:
Multi-Digit Multiplication and
Division
Description:
Multiply a whole number of up to four digits by a one-digit whole number, and multiply two two-
digit numbers, using strategies based on place value and the properties of operations. Illustrate
and explain the calculation by using equations, rectangular arrays, and/or area models. 71
Goal:
Use place value understanding and properties of operations to perform multi-digit arithmetic. (Grade 4
expectations in this domain are limited to whole numbers less than or equal to 1,000,000.)

ModuleName:
Multi-Digit Multiplication and
Division
Description:
Find whole-number quotients and remainders with up to four-digit dividends and one-digit
divisors, using strategies based on place value, the properties of operations, and/or the
relationship between multiplication and division. Illustrate and explain the calculation by using
equations, rectangular arrays, and/or area models.
Goal:
Use place value understanding and properties of operations to perform multi-digit arithmetic. (Grade 4
expectations in this domain are limited to whole numbers less than or equal to 1,000,000.)

ModuleName:
Multi-Digit Multiplication and
Division
Description:
Apply the area and perimeter formulas for rectangles in real world and mathematical problems.
For example, find the width of a rectangular room given the area of the flooring and the length,
by viewing the area formula as a multiplication equation with an unknown factor.
Goal: Solve problems involving measurement and conversion of measurements from a larger unit to a smaller unit.

ModuleName:
Angle Measure and Plane
Figures
Description:
Recognize angles as geometric shapes that are formed wherever two rays share a common
endpoint, and understand concepts of angle measurement:
a. An angle is measured with reference to a circle with its center at the common endpoint of
the rays, by considering the fraction of the circular arc between the points where the two
rays intersect the circle. An angle that turns through 1/360 of a circle is called a “one-degree
angle,” and can be used to measure angles.
b. An angle that turns through n one-degree angles is said to have an angle measure of n
degrees.
Goal: Geometric measurement: understand concepts of angle and measure angles.

ModuleName:
Angle Measure and Plane
Figures
Description:
Measure angles in whole-number degrees using a protractor. Sketch angles of specified
measure.
Goal: Geometric measurement: understand concepts of angle and measure angles.

ModuleName:
Angle Measure and Plane
Figures
Description:
Recognize angle measure as additive. When an angle is decomposed into non-overlapping parts,
the angle measure of the whole is the sum of the angle measures of the parts. Solve addition
and subtraction problems to find unknown angles on a diagram in real world and mathematical
problems, e.g., by using an equation with a symbol for the unknown angle measure.
Goal: Geometric measurement: understand concepts of angle and measure angles.

ModuleName:
Angle Measure and Plane
Figures
Description:
Draw points, lines, line segments, rays, angles (right, acute, obtuse), and perpendicular and
parallel lines. Identify these in two-dimensional figures.
Goal: Draw and identify lines and angles, and classify shapes by properties of their lines and angles.

ModuleName:
Angle Measure and Plane
Figures
Description:
Classify two-dimensional figures based on the presence or absence of parallel or perpendicular
lines, or the presence or absence of angles of a specified size. Recognize right triangles as a
category, and identify right triangles.
Goal: Draw and identify lines and angles, and classify shapes by properties of their lines and angles.

ModuleName:
Angle Measure and Plane
Figures
Description:
Recognize a line of symmetry for a two-dimensional figure as a line across the figure such that
the figure can be folded along the line into matching parts. Identify line-symmetric figures and
draw lines of symmetry.
Goal: Draw and identify lines and angles, and classify shapes by properties of their lines and angles.

ModuleName:
Fraction Equivalence, Ordering,
and Operations
Description:
Generate a number or shape pattern that follows a given rule. Identify apparent features of the
pattern that were not explicit in the rule itself. For example, given the rule “Add 3” and the
starting number 1, generate terms in the resulting sequence and observe that the terms appear
to alternate between odd and even numbers. Explain informally why the numbers will continue to
alternate in this way.
Goal: Generate and analyze patterns.

ModuleName:
Fraction Equivalence, Ordering,
and Operations
Description:
Explain why a fraction a/b is equivalent to a fraction (n × a)/(n × b) by using visual fraction
models, with attention to how the number and size of the parts differ even though the two
fractions themselves are the same size. Use this principle to recognize and generate equivalent
fractions.
Goal:
Extend understanding of fraction equivalence and ordering. (Grade 4 expectations in this domain are limited
to fractions with denominators 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, 12, and 100.)

ModuleName:
Fraction Equivalence, Ordering,
and Operations
Description:
Compare two fractions with different numerators and different denominators, e.g., by creating
common denominators or numerators, or by comparing to a benchmark fraction such as 1/2.
Recognize that comparisons are valid only when the two fractions refer to the same whole.
Record the results of comparisons with symbols >, =, or <, and justify the conclusions, e.g., by
using a visual fraction model.
Goal:
Extend understanding of fraction equivalence and ordering. (Grade 4 expectations in this domain are limited
to fractions with denominators 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, 12, and 100.)

ModuleName:
Fraction Equivalence, Ordering,
and Operations
Description:
Understand a fraction a/b with a > 1 as a sum of fractions 1/b.
a. Understand addition and subtraction of fractions as joining and separating parts referring to
the same whole.
b. Decompose a fraction into a sum of fractions with the same denominator in more than one
way, recording each decomposition by an equation. Justify decompositions, e.g., by using a
visual fraction model. Examples: 3/8 = 1/8 + 1/8 + 1/8 ; 3/8 = 1/8 + 2/8 ; 2 1/8 = 1 + 1 + 1/8 =
8/8 + 8/8 + 1/8.
c. Add and subtract mixed numbers with like denominators, e.g., by replacing each mixed
number with an equivalent fraction, and/or by using properties of operations and the
relationship between addition and subtraction.
d. Solve word problems involving addition and subtraction of fractions referring to the same
whole and having like denominators, e.g., by using visual fraction models and equations to
represent the problem.
Goal: Build fractions from unit fractions by applying and extending previous understanding of operations on whole numbers.

ModuleName:
Fraction Equivalence, Ordering,
and Operations
Description:
Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication to multiply a fraction by a whole
number.
a. Understand a fraction a/b as a multiple of 1/b. For example, use a visual fraction model to
represent 5/4 as the product 5 × (1/4), recording the conclusion by the equation 5/4 = 5 ×
(1/4).
b. Understand a multiple of a/b as a multiple of 1/b, and use this understanding to multiply a
fraction by a whole number. For example, use a visual fraction model to express 3 × (2/5) as
6 × (1/5), recognizing this product as 6/5. (In general, n × (a/b) = (n × a)/b.)
c. Solve word problems involving multiplication of a fraction by a whole number, e.g., by using
visual fraction models and equations to represent the problem. For example, if each person
at a party will eat 3/8 of a pound of roast beef, and there will be 5 people at the party, how
many pounds of roast beef will be needed? Between what two whole numbers does your answer lie?
Goal: Build fractions from unit fractions by applying and extending previous understanding of operations on whole numbers.

ModuleName:
Fraction Equivalence, Ordering,
and Operations
Description:
Use the four operations to solve word problems involving distances, intervals of time, liquid
volumes, masses of objects, and money, including problems involving simple fractions or
decimals, and problems that require expressing measurements given in a larger unit in terms of
a smaller unit. Represent measurement quantities using diagrams such as number line diagrams
that feature a measurement scale.
Goal:
Solve problems involving measurement and conversion of measurements from a larger unit to a smaller
unit.

ModuleName:
Fraction Equivalence, Ordering,
and Operations
Description:
Make a line plot to display a data set of measurements in fractions of a unit (1/2, 1/4, 1/8). Solve
problems involving addition and subtraction of fractions by using information presented in line
plots. For example, from a line plot find and interpret the difference in length between the
longest and shortest specimens in an insect collection.
Goal: Represent and interpret data.

ModuleName: Decimal Fractions
Description:
Express a fraction with denominator 10 as an equivalent fraction with denominator 100, and use
this technique to add two fractions with respective denominators 10 and 100. (Students who can
generate equivalent fractions can develop strategies for adding fractions wit unlike
denominators in general. But addition and subtraction with unlike denominators in general is not
a requirement at this grade.) For example, express 3/10 as 30/100, and add 3/10 + 4/100 =
34/100.
Goal:
Understand decimal notations for fractions, and compare decimal fractions. (Grade 4 expectations in this
domain are limited to fractions with denominators 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, 12, and 100.) 75

ModuleName: Decimal Fractions
Description:
Use decimal notation for fractions with denominators 10 or 100. For example, rewrite 0.62 as
62/100; describe a length as 0.62 meters; locate 0.62 on a number line diagram.
Goal:
Understand decimal notations for fractions, and compare decimal fractions. (Grade 4 expectations in this
domain are limited to fractions with denominators 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, 12, and 100.) 75

ModuleName: Decimal Fractions
Description: Compare two decimals to hundredths by reasoning about their size. Recognize that comparisons
Goal:
Understand decimal notations for fractions, and compare decimal fractions. (Grade 4 expectations in this
domain are limited to fractions with denominators 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, 12, and 100.) 75

ModuleName: Decimal Fractions
Description:
Use the four operations to solve word problems involving distances, intervals of time, liquid
volumes, masses of objects, and money, including problems involving simple fractions or
decimals, and problems that require expressing measurements given in a larger unit in terms of
a smaller unit. Represent measurement quantities using diagrams such as number line diagrams
that feature a measurement scale.
Goal:
Solve problems involving measurement and conversion of measurements from a larger unit to a smaller
unit.

ModuleName: Exploring Multiplication
Description:
Interpret a multiplication equation as a comparison, e.g., interpret 35 = 5 x 7 as a statement that
35 is 5 times as many as 7 and 7 times as many as 5. Represent verbal statements of
multiplicative comparisons as multiplication equations.
Goal: Use the four operations with whole numbers to solve problems.

ModuleName: Exploring Multiplication
Description:
Multiply or divide to solve word problems involving multiplicative comparison, e.g., by using
drawings and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem,
distinguishing multiplicative comparison from additive comparison. (See Glossary, Table 2.)
Goal: Use the four operations with whole numbers to solve problems.

ModuleName: Exploring Multiplication
Description:
Solve multistep word problems posed with whole numbers and having whole-number answers
using the four operations, including problems in which remainders must be interpreted.
Represent these problems using equations with a letter standing for the unknown quantity.
Assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies
including rounding.
Goal: Use the four operations with whole numbers to solve problems.

ModuleName: Exploring Multiplication
Description:
Multiply a whole number of up to four digits by a one-digit whole number, and multiply two two-
digit numbers, using strategies based on place value and the properties of operations. Illustrate
and explain the calculation by using equations, rectangular arrays, and/or area models.
Goal: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to perform multi-digit arithmetic.
SUBJECTL2: NUMBERS AND OPERATIONS IN BASE TEN

ModuleName: Exploring Multiplication
Description:
Know relative sizes of measurement units within one system of units including km, m, cm; kg, g;
lb, oz.; l, ml; hr, min, sec. Within a single system of measurement, express measurements in a
larger unit in terms of a smaller unit. Record measurement equivalents in a two-column table.
For example, know that 1 ft is 12 times as long as 1 in. Express the length of a 4 ft snake as 48 in.
Generate a conversion table for feet and inches listing the number pairs (1, 12), (2, 24), (3, 36), ...
Goal:
Solve problems involving measurement and conversion of measurements from a larger unit to a smaller
unit.
SUBJECTL2: NUMBERS AND OPERATIONS IN BASE TEN

ModuleName: Exploring Multiplication
Description:
Use the four operations to solve word problems involving distances, intervals of time, liquid
volumes, masses of objects, and money, including problems involving simple fractions or
decimals, and problems that require expressing measurements given in a larger unit in terms of
a smaller unit. Represent measurement quantities using diagrams such as number line diagrams
that feature a measurement scale.
Goal:
Solve problems involving measurement and conversion of measurements from a larger unit to a smaller
unit.
SUBJECTL2: NUMBERS AND OPERATIONS IN BASE TEN

ModuleName: Place Value and Decimal Fractions
Description:
Recognize that in a multi-digit number, a digit in one place represents 10 times as much as it
represents in the place to its right and 1/10 of what it represents in the place to its left.
Goal: Understand the place value system.
SUBJECTL2: NUMBERS AND OPERATIONS IN BASE TEN

ModuleName: Place Value and Decimal Fractions
Description:
Explain patterns in the number of zeros of the product when multiplying a number by powers of
10, and explain patterns in the placement of the decimal point when a decimal is multiplied or
divided by a power of 10. Use whole-number exponents to denote powers of 10.
Goal: Understand the place value system.
SUBJECTL2: NUMBERS AND OPERATIONS IN BASE TEN

ModuleName: Place Value and Decimal Fractions
Description:
Read, write, and compare decimals to thousandths.
a. Read and write decimals to thousandths using base-ten numerals, number names, and
expanded form, e.g., 347.392 = 3 × 100 + 4 × 10 + 7 × 1 + 3 × (1/10) + 9 × (1/100) + 2 ×
(1/1000).
b. Compare two decimals to thousandths based on meanings of the digits in each place, using
>, =, and < symbols to record the results of comparisons.
Goal: Understand the place value system.
SUBJECTL2: NUMBERS AND OPERATIONS IN BASE TEN

ModuleName: Place Value and Decimal Fractions
Description: Use place value understanding to round decimals to any place.
Goal: Understand the place value system.
SUBJECTL2: NUMBERS AND OPERATIONS IN BASE TEN
